title: Orient to the Carpal Grid
summary: Walk through proximal and distal carpal rows, landmarking each bone and their articulations so learners can visualize the grid before layering mechanics.
high_yield: Remember the lateral-to-medial sequence (Scaphoid to Pisiform, Trapezium to Hamate) because it drives palpation and injury localization.
Capitate sits central and anchors the wrist axis—mention this before discussing midcarpal motion.
Hook of the hamate is a frequent compression site (ulnar nerve/artery) to flag for clinical translation.
pitfalls: Learners often swap trapezium and trapezoid—highlight thumb alignment to prevent this.
Pisiform is sesamoid; emphasize it rides volar to the triquetrum so it is not mis-labeled as a carpal partner.

animation_timeline.narration: Start with a dorsal wrist silhouette. Fade in proximal row bones labeled from scaphoid to pisiform.
animation_timeline.visual: Outline carpal grid; sequential highlight scaphoid→lunate→triquetrum→pisiform with captions.

animation_timeline.narration: Bring on the distal row, anchoring trapezium at the thumb side and sweeping medially.
animation_timeline.visual: Add distal row overlay; animate labels trapezium→trapezoid→capitate→hamate.

animation_timeline.narration: Call out key articulations: scaphoid with radius, lunate with radius, capitate pivot, hamate hook.
animation_timeline.visual: Pulse contact surfaces; draw arrows from bones to articulation callouts on side panel.
